RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN - SANTA MARIA, CA FACILITY



Executive Summary



General Description



Accidental Release and Emergency Response Policies



Pictsweet is committed to providing a safe environment to its employees and surrounding communities.  This commitment is reflected in the safety and environmental programs that are implemented at the facility.  For example, written procedures have been created for operating the ammonia refrigeration system.  Only trained operators are permitted to perform system operations.  Pictsweet has also developed a robust maintenance program to ensure the equipment is in good operating condition.  All of these programs are geared towards the prevention of an accidental release at the facility.  In addition, these programs incorporate emergency procedures to mitigate the effects of a release if it does occur.  At such an event, emergency coordinators will assess the situation and notify outside responding agencies as necessary.



Stationary Source and Regulated Substance



Pictsweet is located at 732 S. Hanson Way in Santa Maria, California.  Ammonia is used in the facility's refrigeration system to provide cooling for the storage of vegetables.  The system uses a maximum of 80,000 pounds of ammonia.  A description of how the process operates is presented below:  



Liquid ammonia in the high pressure receivers is fed to the intercoolers, the surge drums associated with the water chillers, and the flash cooler. They also provide liquid to the compressors for oil cooling.  The intercoolers and flash cooler provide liquid to the recirculators.  Pumps at the recirculators provide liquid to the freezer evaporators, plate freezers, IQF tunnels, and spiral freezers. At the evaporators/tunnels/freezers, air is drawn over the coils by the fans. he RMP criteria for a reportable accident (onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place).  In addition, there have been no incidents at the facility in the last five years that resulted in a release of more than the Federal Reportable Quantity (100 pounds).



Emergency Response Program



Pictsweet has developed an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) for the purpose of protecting employees and the surrounding community.  The ERP covers procedures for: 1) evacuating and accounting for visitors and employees, 2) the onsite Emergency Response Team responding to an ammonia release and other foreseeable emergencies that could occur onsite, 3) notifying external agencies and additional emergency response personnel, and 4) administering first aid measures for ammonia exposure.  Members on the team are trained on their responsibilities. Employees are informed of the elements of the ERP.  In the event of an ammonia release, employees will evacuate or shelter-in-place, depending on the nature of the release. If additional assistance is needed, the facility will contact the refrigeration contractor (C.I.M. Electric, 805-928-8605) and the fire department (Santa Barbara County Fire Department, 805-934-6292, and City of Santa Maria Fire Department, 805-925-0951).



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Process Hazard Analyses and Compliance Audits have been performed on the ammonia refrigeration system, and these studies have resulted in action items to improve safety at the facility.  The recommendations mainly consist of formalizing procedures, implementing practices consistent with industry standards, and performing inspections and tests to maintain the integrity of the equipment.  Pictsweet has implemented several of these action items and is moving forward with completing the remaining outstanding recommendations. In addition, the facility plans to continue pr
oviding employees with a safe work environment through continued training on current policies and procedures, and conducting audits to identify deficiencies and make improvements.
